results.title: Carmen
results.creator_credit: Gavin Taylor, Ken Scorfield, Allied Vision and Classical Productions
results.brief_description: The lavish and spectacular television production of Georges Bizet’s “Carmen”, staged at London’s Earls Court in June 1989, proved beyond doubt the resounding success of opera on such a grand scale. Playing to sell-out audiences of over twelve thousand at each performance, the production drew rave reviews from all the critics. Starring Maria Ewing, who has now made this part her own, “Carmen” was staged in the centre of Earls Court, surrounded on all sides by the audience to create the atmosphere of a Spanish bullring.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gavin Taylor, Ken Scorfield, Allied Vision and Classical Productions

results.title: Carlton + Godard = cinema [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Nigel Buesst and Sunrise Picture Company
results.brief_description:
A retrospective look at the film-making movement in Carlton during the 1960s/1970s, the filmmakers and the influences that inspired and motivated them. Includes an examination of the life and work of neo-realist Giorgio Mangiamele, and the French new wave styles of Brian Davies, Peter Carmody, Antony I. Ginnane, Peter Elliot, James Clayden, Nigel Buesst, David Minter. An assembly of extracts from several of the Carlton films are juxtaposed with pieces of Godard’s early films revealing much about a fascinating period of Melbourne filmmaking.
Features Antony I. Ginnane, Geoffrey Gardner, James Clayden, Bob Garlick, Giancarlo Giusti, Graeme Cutts. Narrated by Peter Fisher.

results.title: Caring for our country
results.brief_description: Examines three major environmental problems with regards to land use. These are salinity, soil erosion and tree decline. The video explores the ways in which today’s farmers take responsibility for land degradation and the strategies they use to deal with these problems.

results.title: Captured in time: favourites of the fifties from the Cinesound / Movietone newsreels.
results.creator_credit: Norm Wilkinson, Bluestone Productions and Film World
results.brief_description: Years before television bought the news into our loungeroom, the Cinesound and Movietone news delighted and informed the cinema goers of Australia. This video contains news stories from the 1950’s including Australia at war with Korea, the Redex Trial in 1955 and the filming of Neville Shute’s “On the beach” in Melbourne.
results.title_for_label: Captured in time: favourites of the fifties from the Cinesound / Movietone newsreels.

results.title: Captive minds: hypnosis and beyond
results.creator_credit: Pierre Lasry, Adam Symansky, David Wilson, Mark Zannis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From stage hypnosis to group and individual therapies and long-term conditioning, “Captive minds: hypnosis and beyond” explores the power of suggestion and its ability to influence behaviour - sometimes for life. By focusing on such disparate institutions as an Indian ashram, a United States Marines training camp, a monastery, and the Moonie cult, the film reveals the striking similarities in the indoctrination methods each uses to achieve long-term effects. It is a film that serves as a reminder that we are all vulnerable to persuasion, and one that provokes serious consideration of the far-reaching implications of any form of psychological manipulation. Awards: San Francisco; Montreal
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pierre Lasry, Adam Symansky, David Wilson, Mark Zannis and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Captain Pugwash Seafaring Tales
results.brief_description: Attention me hearties! Here’s another chance to watch that bravest of buccaneers, Captain Pugwash, and his trusty band of pirates, in nine salty tales from the hugely popular 1960s and 70s series. Thrill to their swash- buckling adventures aboard the Black Pig as cunning cabin boy Tom helps Captain Pugwash and his loyal crew battle against their arch-enemy Cut Throat Jake. Their adventures involve an hilarious smuggling escapade, doughnuts for dodos and even a promising career in the theatre … but is it the end for Captain Pugwash when he faces the chopper? Rated: G

results.title: Captured in time: favourites from the sixties from the Cinesound / Movietone newsreels.
results.brief_description: In the years before television, millions of Australians made the weekly pilgramage to cinemas to catch the latest edition of the Cinesound and Movietone News. This video includes newsreels of the last lamplighter in Australia and the visit of American President, Lyndon B. Johnson.

results.title: Captives of care
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallace, Don Catchlove and Sydney Filmmakers Co-operative
results.brief_description: A dramatic reconstruction of events which occurred at “Leumah”, a residential institution for physically handicapped adults, during 1973. Tells of the residents’ struggle to gain a measure of autonomy, and the obstacles which were put in their way. Adapted from the book “Captives of Care” by John Roarty. Cast includes: Julieanne Newbould, Pat Thomson, Kay Taylor, Phillip Hinton, Tony Ward and John Roarty.

results.title: Cappuccino
results.creator_credit: Antony J. Bowman, Sue Wild and Archer Films
results.brief_description: A taxi-driver yearns to be a stand-up comic. He narrates the story about a group of middle aged actors and actresses who meet regularly at an inner-city cafe to discuss their relationships and work or attempts to obtain roles. Stars John Clayton and Rowena Wallace.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Antony J. Bowman, Sue Wild and Archer Films

results.title: Cannibal Tours
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, Chris Owen and Laurence J. Henderson
results.brief_description: This witty, charming film follows a group of rich and bourgeois tourists on a journey along the Sepik River in the jungles of Papua New Guinea. The camera watches and assesses as the travellers meet the natives who live in the villages along the route. The two sides tell their own stories, revealing to the viewer the comparisons between them. Above all, “Cannibal Tours” affords us a glimpse of the real reasons why “civilised” people wish to encounter the “primitive”. Rated: PG
